column2: This province is occupied by enemies and many precious lives have been lost.
Our enemies will pay for this...

Though the Men of the West replenish their numbers slowly, during times of plenty you can expend gold and influence to encourage young Dúnedain families to have more children. You should see results within twenty years.
Yes, make efforts to increase population in a random province
Yes, make the effort where my steward is located
The population in [Root.GetName], with the expenditure of a great amount of wealth and influence, has grown greatly in the last 20 years.
With money and time, you can increase the Dúnedain population in this province, booting levy size and wealth.
With money and time, you can increase the Dwarven population in this province, booting levy size and wealth
With money and time, you can increase the Elven population in this province, booting levy size and wealth
With money and time, you can increase the population in this province, booting levy size and wealth
The Dúnedain are waning in Middle-Earth, and there are few of them left in this province.
This province is well settled by Dúnedain.

In this province there are still many men of high blood, and though there may be other cities more crowded and populous, the natural gifts of the Dúnedain ensure that this land is both wealthy and well protected.
The Elves are leaving Middle-Earth, and there are few of them left in this province.
This province is well settled by Elves.
Though not 'densely populated' in the human or orcish sense, there are a great many elves in this province and the lands are both wealthy and well guarded..
Dwarves still hold this province, but their numbers are few.
This province is well settled by dwarves. Though not a numerous people, here at least they have the strength of numbers to protect their lands and maintain their great halls.
The dwarves here are prospering, and though they will never reach the numbers that men and orcs can field, this land is well guarded and the population is steadily increasing.

Though Elves replenish their numbers slowly, during times of plenty you can expend gold and influence to encourage your people to have more children. You should see results within twenty years. NOTE: There is no point doing so in a densely populated province.

Though Dwarves replenish their numbers slowly, during times of plenty you can expend gold and influence to encourage your people to have more children. You should see results within twenty years. NOTE: There is no point doing so in a densely populated province..

During times of plenty you can expend gold and influence to encourage your people to have more children. You should see results within twenty years. NOTE: There is no point doing so in a densely populated province..
There are hostile creatures in your realm, they must be purged and the threat removed. It might take a decade to destroy them fully, so it's time to send in the troops...
At least one of your provinces has been purged of enemies, and now the time will come to settle the new wilderness with your people.
There are enemies, weaklings or not, in your territories, and your people hunger for their Flesh. They must be smashed!
At least one of your provinces has been cleared of enemies, driven away, killed, or eaten. Now your people are swarming in to settle the abandoned places.
There are peoples living in your lands who will never submit to you. It's time to send in the troops and get rid of them once and for all.
At least one of your provinces has been cleared of enemies, and your servant Orcs are swarming in to settle the abandoned places.
This province is responsible for building a new colony in unsettled lands, and a large amount of treasure and troops are used for this process. Hence, a tax and levy penalty applies.
Do you want to colonize this province? It can take up to 20 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it expends its resources in the new lands.
Yes, our people need new lands to settle.
[Root.GetName] has been colonised, and will now start paying taxes and contributing troops to your realm. The wilderness has given way to settlements, and your people will surely prosper here.

A dwarf noble is in your court. It will be extremely costly, but you can send him to convince some of his people to settle in a new province, while you start building the infrastructure and clearing the lands of enemies.
Yes, dwarves will live in this province.
[Root.GetName] has been settled by dwarves, who will be a valuable addition to your realm.

An elven noble is in your court. It will be extremely costly, but you can send him to convince some of his people to settle in a new province, while you start building the infrastructure and clearing the lands of enemies.
Yes, elves will live in this province.
[Root.GetName] has been settled by Elves, who will be a valuable addition to your realm.

An influential halfing is in your court. It will be very costly, but you can send him to convince some of his people to settle in a new province, while you start building the infrastructure and clearing the lands of enemies.
Yes, halflings will live in this province.
[Root.GetName] has been settled by Halflings, who will be a valuable addition to your realm
Being colonised with Gondorian Middle Men
Being colonised with Arnorian Middle Men
It will be very expensive to settle these lands with those of Dúnedain ancestry, as their numbers are few. Do you want to settle with middle men instead?
No, this province will be for the High Men.
Yes, send in some Gondorian Middle-Men.
Yes, send in some Arnorian Middle-Men.
Yes, send in some Southrons instead.
[Root.GetName] has been settled by Gondorian Middle Men, who will be a valuable addition to your realm.
[Root.GetName] has been settled by Arnorian Middle Men, who will be a valuable addition to your realm.
[Root.GetName] has been settled by Southrons, who will be a valuable addition to your realm.
This province has been settled by the High Men, who will be a valuable addition to your realm.
Though populations grow slowly, in this province a lot of effort has been expended to increase the population, and within 20 years results should be shown.
Mountains and hills are natural dwarven territory.

Do you want to colonize this province? Your Dwarves believe it may be rich, but this can take up to 40 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it expends its resources to colonize the Mountains.
Yes, the Dwarves need new Halls and Forges.
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by your Dwarves, and new Forges and Halls have been built
Dwarves prefer mountains and hills, but you can try to colonize anyway.

Do you want to colonize this province? Your Dwarves dislike the lack of mountains, but money can persuade them to move. This can take up to 40 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it expends its resources to colonize the Mountains.
The Realm needs this. Strike the Earth!
Defy the usual trend by colonizing this wilderness with your people, Elves

Do you want to colonize this province? Elves may be dwindling, but with effort, you can grow. This can take up to 60 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it expends its resources supporting the colonization.
Yes, Middle-Earth is for Elves too.

The High Elves are few, and the Valar want them in Aman. Perhaps you could colonize with Wood Elves instead. Either way, this could take up to 60 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it expends its resources supporting the colonization.
No, this province will be for the High Elves.
Yes, send in some Wood Elves.
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by your Elves, proving Elves can also grow.
Amazingly, [Root.GetName] is now successfully colonized by High Elves!
[Root.GetName] is now colonised by Wood Elves, proving Elves can also grow.
Colonize this Wilderness with Humans, which could be quicker and cheaper than using your own kind.

Do you wish to have Humans colonize this province? It will cost money, but your own people may be unable, or be too slow or costly, to colonize themselves. This can take up to 20 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it supports the colonisation.
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by Humans, and will now start paying taxes and contributing troops to your realm.
Pay the hardy Forodwaith to settle in this province.

This Arctic province is too harsh for most, but the Forodwaith have the knowledge and culture to settle it. Do you want to colonize this province with them? This can take up to 20 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it supports the colonisation.
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by Forodwaith, and can now be taxed and perhaps will even give toops one day.
Colonize this Wilderness with Orcs (or Trolls).

Do you want to colonize this province? As an Evil Overlord ruling over Orcs (or perhaps Trolls), you can order some of them to colonize this province. This can take up to 20 years, and one of your demesne provinces will suffer tax and levy penalties while it expends its resources supporting the colonization. You can pick from available cultures, even the Uruk-Hai if you rule over some and have enough wealth.
This is now an Evil province
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by Orc-Kind, and can now be taxed and and used as a source of troops
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by Wargs, who actually don't exist.
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by Trolls. May thier brute strength bring victory!
[Root.GetName] has now been colonised by creepy Spiders, whose webs will snare trespassers (if they are weak).
